required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Temperature Monitoring in Cardiac Surgery: Agreement Between Different Clinical Methods
clinical_study.official_title: Temperature Monitoring in Cardiac Surgery: Clinical Study of Agreement Between Different Measurement Methods

lead_sponsor.agency: Fundación Instituto de Estudios de Ciencias de la Salud de Castilla y León

clinical_study.source: Fundación Instituto de Estudios de Ciencias de la Salud de Castilla y León

brief_summary.textblock: Observational study to compare core temperatures obtained by 6 methods in patients undergoing cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass.

detailed_description.textblock: This study compares the core temperatures obtained by means of different probes placed in nasopharinx, pulmonary artery, arterial outlet, venous inlet, bladder and forehead in patients undergoing cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass.

primary_outcome.measure: Agreement between different core temperature methods
primary_outcome.time_frame: 24 temperature measures per patient recorded at 5-min intervals during surgery (8 readings in the pre-CPB period, 8 during the CPB period and 8 aftr CPB period)
primary_outcome.description: Agreement between core temperatures obtained in arterial output and venous inlet of CPB, bladder, pulmonary artery, nasopharinx and forehead (Tcore)

intervention.description: Monitoring core temperatures with probes placed in the arterial outlet and venous inlet of extracorporeal pump, pulmonary artery, bladder, nasopharinx and forehead using a doublé-sensor probe

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing cardiac surgery under cardiovascular bypass

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Only patients requiring a pulmonary artery catheter were included.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Sepsis or previous fever.
- Previous bladder catheter without termistor
- Deep hypothermic circulatory arrest.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Fundación Instituto de Estudios de Ciencias de la Salud de Castilla y León
